course.name: English for University Studies II
course.description: The course builds on LANG 1002 and aims to further develop students' proficiency in English as well as their academic literacy skills, so that they can cope with the linguistic demands of studying through the medium of English. For students under the four-year degree curriculum.

The grading scheme is as follows:

Part A Multimodal Project (in total 70%):
25% - Academic blogs--individual blog posts on academic readings/research  
Academic blog #1: Summary and critique of an article (e.g., magazines, journals)  
Academic blog #2: Comparison/critique/synthesis of 2 more articles (e.g., magazines, journals, websites, news)
5% - An in-class sharing session of videos draft/storyboard for peers and teacher
30% - A group multimodal report with Q&A session based on the synthesis of individual research
5% for teamwork
5% for peer feedback

Part B Self-Directed Learning (in total 30%):
10% SDL
5% Eletives
15% Reflection(3 of them)

Final Grade: A
Note that I get almost everything full. Except for reflection and academic blog 2. But still thank Yilmaz for his generosity
reviews.comment_workload:
This semester I have taken 18 credits and I strongly believe that this 3 credits course has a higher workload than my other 15 credits...
I don't mind working on academic blogs or videos or SDL or what. But all of them together??? That's a torture lol. Every week you have to spend like 2 hours working on different SDL (in total 13 of them) and they only account for 10% of the course grade???? Not to mention that there also are "Electives'' that take you another 4 hours which only count 5% towards your grade.
Then it comes to the multimodal project. First you have to finish 2 academic blogs, then a storyboard section to somehow share what you are going to do for your video, then finally a 8-minute video that has to be made by yourselves. Though it is a group project, the workload is still immense. Just producing and editing the video can take you 6 hours or above. It is just a pure headache. (Luckily I get very supportive groupmates, if you get some free-riders in your group.....Gosh)
So, CLE, please try to fix your course and whoever design this course please be more empathetic to your students and let us be the last sufferers.

reviews.comment_grading:
For all details including data, please refer to the attached document.

Grading is a bit looser than the S stream, I think, as I was in LANG 1003S in fall semester. You may get 1 mark higher in each category in the A stream. The A stream instructor would probably expect a mean of around 5~6 out of 7.

There is one hint for the score of grammar of essay tasks. In ELPA, it is noted that English proficiency is the one it tests us. Should you be good in English, content score is not a big issue. To get a better grammar score, you may make a list as shown in the following before writing.

- inversion
- conditional sentence
- relative clauses
- gerund
...

When you are writing the essay, cross out the items you have used. This might be useful for those who are not confident with your English or those going from the S stream to the A stream.
reviews.comment_workload:
Fair workload. In average, there will be one assignment or task each month. Unlike classes in the S stream, there was no extra assignments for A stream students.

As for the writing task, you had better search for more information first so that enough proof or evidence can support your view. Evidence is important for content in the writing task, unlike ELPA.

reviews.author: KaochanKDDR
reviews.title: Seems like the "experimental" curriculum doesn't work *chuckles*
reviews.comment_content:
The teacher has explicitly told us that this is a pilot, experimental course that is tried for the first time. Nevertheless, I still give my truthful judgement, hope she can take it and seriously improve it for the next gen of students.
Yes, the content for this course deserves an E. There's practically nothing to learn other than the "find academic paper" skill that got taught in just one lesson. All the other stuff are just work, like suddenly we just become workers and not students or learners. And we also didn't get taught anything, there are assignments after assignments, SDLs, academic blog, video project, and we just use whatever we have to deal with it. So unironically, from the course what I improve on the most are video editing, time management and pressure management skills, while gaining close to none in my English (or probably even worsen it, given how many time I have to give up on formality just to finish the task and throw it off my head).

TLDR: Nothing to learn, you basically are sent to the workforce.
reviews.comment_teaching: Other than her always-cheerful, motivating attitude and just being nice, there's little she managed to teach or at least help us. We were still largely left alone, swimming desperately in this monstrous sea of workload and assignments. At least she gave instructions on what we have to do in time, so well, she got the bare minimum of teacher standard. And at least her cheerful attitude made us work harder than we should be, otherwise, this course would just crumble under extreme anxiety and depression.
reviews.comment_grading:
I don't even bother uploading the grading scheme on here, since it is still such a horrendous nightmare that I just want to wipe from my memory and never look back again. They try to divide the grades into the tini tiniest bit detail, and sometimes you have to work so so hard (like 2-3 hours extra) just to gain 1-2% extra grade. Given how meaningless some of the tasks are (I said most of the stuff are plain work and no learning, but some are even more meaningless than others, just a bunch of wasteful bureaucratic work that never will be bothered again), I even ignored some tasks completely, showing my objection to work, thus resulting in my low score (B-). But even without my objection, I think the score is still quite low, given how we are basically turned into lab rat, and the instructor had promised lenient score for us.

TLDR: The grading is terrible, both on the scheme and the final letter score.
reviews.comment_workload:
From the three other sections, you probably could already imagine what the workload looks like. And for me, the guy who carried the whole storyboarding and video editing section of the group, I just got a once-in-a-lifetime experience *haha very funny*. I must have spent 100-odd hours for every mini tasks and microservices embedded in this course, and for the first time in my life, I worked for 30+ hours straight, no sleep (basically skip 2 nights), simple eating and a few short 10-minute breaks. In class when I have to present our video, my mouth doesn't even work properly lol, and after the class ended, I rammed onto bed and basically got blackouted for the next 8 hours of my life. Feels like a total war really, and I barely won, at the expense of being torn apart both physically and mentally. Luckily I'm still young and got recovered from that to combat the rest of the finals :v

TLDR: Simply torture lol, if this course got prolonged, probably even worse than 996. At least 996 workers still work for sth meaningful, but all our work... is for what??

Participation: 10%

Writing (Beauty): 30%

Participation: Unknown, maybe 3/4 ?

reviews.comment_grading:
The grading is actually an oxymoron of being clarified and vague:
5% of the grade is coming from your performance in the class, which means it also counts attendance and how enthusiastic you are in the class. (Is actually pretty pale when compared to that of 1002, which counts for 10%)
15% of the grade counts the two vocabulary test, which by now, you know what it is.
20% is for the writing task, where you will write an academic essay for a specific topic.
20% is for the speaking task, which is a group discussion.
The rest of the grade depends on your 2nd ELPA test, that's right, the LANG courses' objective is to boost your English proficiency, which is determined by the ELPA tests. The second ELPA test actually determines how much improvement you made in the past.
Overall, I received an A-. Though, the scores of the writing and speaking tasks and vocabulary test is open for me. The rest of it, though, did not disclose to me either.

reviews.title: A poorly designed course with tremendously heavy workload
reviews.comment_content:
The syllabus of this course is non-sense and is totally useless for learning English.
To begin with, the theme of this course is "21st-century study and work", which your multimodal group project is about. In this course, most of the assignments and activities are related to the group project, including two academic blogs, a storyboard, and a video with multimodality elements followed by a 3 minutes presentation (mainly for the conclusion and Q&A). To be honest, I don't see how dealing with multimodality elements (such as creating an animation or editing a video) is related to learning English. It is not only meaningless but also adds extra burdens to students.
Other than the content related to the group project, there're also many other assignments that are mostly useless for English learning, including but not limited to the tasks in Perusall, the "learning to learn" tasks and the electives, as well as the electives.
reviews.comment_teaching: The only reason I give an A for this terrible course in this criteria is due to my tutor: Mariah Chan. Not only that she's really kind and will try her best to make the tutorials less boring, but she also understands students' burden under the unreasonable workload of this course, giving students assistance whenever they need it. And most importantly, her gradings are reasonable and she's really efficient at replying students' emails. I strongly suggest you to swap to her classes if you expect better learning experiences in this course.
reviews.comment_grading:
The gradings are divided into two main parts: "multimodal project" and "self-directed learning".

Multimodal project (70%)
• academic blog 1----------10%
• academic blog 2----------10%
• use of sources (for both academic blogs)----------5%
• in-class sharing session of video draft/storyboard----------5%
• multimodal report with Q&A----------30%
• teamwork----------5%
• peer feedback----------5%

Self-directed learning (30%)
• online/out of class work----------10%
• electives ("learning to learn"+2 more electives)----------5%
• reflection----------15% (each task accounts for 5%)
    • speaking (a solution to a problem associated with this course)
    • writing (reflection on multimodal communication in your group project)
    • looking forward (evaluating progress in this course and setting new goals for your future)

it is absolutely possible to get all or almost all the scores in the "self-directed learning part". So I suggest not to leave them alone just because they're annoying and the scores they contribute don't make sense compared to their workloads.

And for my grade, I got an A- in that course, Not too bad.
reviews.comment_workload: There're way too many things to do for simply a 3-credits course. You have to finish one or more tasks on Perusall or other platforms almost every week, depending on the timetable. You also have to spend time making a video with ideally 3 or more multimodality elements for your group project. Not to mention that you're also required to complete 3 reflection tasks at the end of this course, which accounts for 5% of the scores in total. Yes, you have to write two short articles and make a presentation to explain how "useful" and "meaningful" this course is after suffering from it!! Just to get those 15% scores!!!!! Since the course grading of LANG1003 is based on the curve, you might get a poor grade if you don't complete them. So you have no choices.

reviews.comment_content:
Somewhat interesting. It is based on two topics:
1. Beauty
2. Happiness
And we have to write an academic argumentative essay about beauty (You decide the topic, as long as it is about beauty), as well as have an academic group discussion about happiness.

Besides the assessed tasks, you have to do other tasks like vocabulary learning (Vocabulary quizzes). In lessons, you have to engage in discussions and learn the skills of English language at the same time.

Note that you are going to take the ELPA test that also counts for the grades if you take this course in the spring semester.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Rosie did excellent work in teaching the classes. She does put a lot of effort into the classes and used various activities for us to learn. For example, conducting a small-scale survey, group discussions about the vocabulary collations before vocabulary quiz, etc.

She also makes use of the technologies to help us to learn English effectively. For example, she told us to set up a Padlet page that stores all our findings of the topics, using Flipgrid to practice for individual presentation (ELPA speaking), and introduces us Vocabulary.com and Quizlet cards for vocabulary learning for vocabulary quizzes.

Rosie also gives useful and detailed feedback to students, that she points out what we can do better.
reviews.comment_grading:
The grading percentage are as follows:
Vocabulary Quiz 1/2: 5%/10%
Other Vocabulary Learning: 5%
Participation Marks: 10%
Writing Task  - Essay/Reflective Statement: 20%/10%
Speaking Task - Group Discussion: 20%
ELPA Speaking: 8%
ELPA Writing: 12%

Note that ELPA is cut from 5 papers to 2 papers due to the special arrangement of this semester.
Try to aim for all 5 on assessed tasks and ELPA, and about 60 ~ 70% for vocabulary quizzes, you are pretty much safe for B-range to A-range.
reviews.comment_workload:
Sadly to say, Rosie's class would be quite harsh in terms of workload, but every extra workload she gave us (compared to other classes) has a clear reason behind. Thus, you have to manage time well if you want to strive for good grades while bearing the work of other courses at the same time. For example, the course requires us to hand in the essay by the end of week 7. For Rosie's class, we have to finish the full essay *draft* before the first lesson of week 6.

reviews.author: Tommy Li
reviews.title: Thank God it's not C-range
reviews.comment_content:
The topic of this semester is beauty and happiness. The content and skills are not particularly interesting. Don't have expectations for interesting content for a LANG course.

reviews.comment_teaching:

There's lots of discussions to prepare you for your speaking task. The amount of discussions chur the class too much, and almost nobody wants to talk near the end of the lesson. I think it depends on people. Some people like more practice chance and some may want to listen for more skills instead of purely doing practices.

In every lesson, you will be shuffled to random groups for discussion. That is, you will get new groupmates every lesson. It  is good that you can practice with different people. However, that hinders the chance for making new friends. I did meet some good friends in LANG 1002 but not here.

reviews.author: Szczesny
reviews.title: Probably the best lecturer you can get in HKUST
reviews.comment_content: Nothing special about the content, it is the same every year, beauty and happiness.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Melissa was the course coordinator for both LANG1002 and LANG1003, she is a very experienced lecturer who has been working in HKUST for more than 20 years. Melissa is very well prepared during class, and always give some valuable materials to get students prepared for different tests, like vocabulary test.

Before every task, Melissa will organize a consultation with every student. Considering the fact many other lecturers don't do this, Melissa actually cares about the learning progress of the students. This is actually a very useful session since you can get very good feedback from Melissa and learn from your mistakes, and of course, Melissa is more than willing to answer the questions.

Melissa's teaching style is not boring at all as she always try to get students engaged by asking questions, or even inviting some students to speak during class. However, this teaching style may not suit some students who are shy to speak, especially those Hong Kong local students.
reviews.comment_grading:
Melissa is very fair is grading, you get what you deserved. Though some may say Melissa is somewhat demanding, Melissa once said "I am just grading all your assignments by judging whether you can meet the descriptions in the grading criteria". Definitely, she is not a killer, she is an absolute fair grader.

Pay attention to her instructions and expectations, and show it in your work, then Melissa will give you decent scores for sure. I got 5.8/7 on average for all the assessments except ELPA. My ELPA score was a bit low which pull me down to around 5.7/7 on average, still, I got an A in LANG1003.

LANG1003 picked absolute grading system in 2017-18 FALL, an average of 5/7 will be the cutoff score for A-.
reviews.comment_workload:
Compare to other lecturers, workload in Melissa's class is slightly heavier since she would ask us to do some homework before the next class. Those homework won't take you a lot of time, say around 30 mins, students who often has his/her preparation work done will definitely get extra credits under "Participation".

Throughout the whole course, just 1 essay, 1 group discussion task, 2 vocab tests and ELPA. It was actually of low workload.

reviews.author: sjn

reviews.author: thm

reviews.author: VLi
reviews.title: The kind of course you can ace
reviews.comment_content:
2 Modules: Beauty and Happiness.
Just a supplement of LANG1002; you will learn how to read fast and talk better. Most of the class will be you trying to learn and practice how to organize your speech within a very short period of time.
Your knowledge of Beauty and Happiness will greatly increase.
It might be boring and monotonous but at least it's nothing difficult.
reviews.comment_teaching:
I am confident to say that Delian is one of the best instructors that the UST LANG department can offer.
She is professional, patient and knowledgeable.
She is the kind of instructor that is willing to stay after class for 30 mins to an hour to review your essays and address your inquiries. As long as you demonstrate the want to learn, she will show you how to be a better student in this course.
Although she gives students the impression that she is result-oriented and talks about getting a 6 or 7 in ELPA in the first class, she is the best for you if you're all about good grades.
reviews.comment_grading:
2 major assessments: Writing task and Speaking (Group discussion) Task.
She is not necessarily lenient on grading; she will only give out a score that is most suitable for you, so make sure you improve your English in this course.
There will vocab tests which you will not have the time to study for.
However, whatever is graded in class is only 60%.

You will have to attempt the ELPA test by the end of the course, which is 40% of your final grade. So make sure you practice and learn about the test before attempting it.
reviews.comment_workload:
As long as you follow Delians guidelines and instructions, you will improve. She will assign you materials to read every week, if you have to discipline to follow her instructions, you might experience a higher workload and a higher grade eventually. So this varies from student to student.

As stated in the grading section, you will have to work hard on perfecting the writing assessment and the speaking assessment. Yet as you will be given plenty of time and opportunity to practice, you won't have to worry about having to work hard on your own.

Spending some time learning vocabs will help in your ELPA.

As it is a group task, after introducing your own ideas by taking turns (like dse chin), you are asked to discuss in a group and reach a consensus. In the group part, to obtain higher grades, you have to have substance in what you are talking about and you are allowed to take a reference sheet for that. For your reference, I didn't write my pitch script there I just wrote indicators of Gross National Happiness and the reasons why people in Finland are happy. I used them and Melissa was impressed.

For participation, just stay active and she will remember you.

For Elpa, go on elpa website to see the grading rubrics before attending the exam. You will be fine.

Overall, pretty easy considering that I only spent one whole day for the writing assessed task (880 words max) and two hours for the group discussion.

reviews.comment_teaching:

Sue's instructions and explanations can be seldom misleading and unclear. Her comments for the writing assessment can be unhelpful, as she merely notes "not understood" and does not clarify what she meant (the room for the writing improvement is thus quite limited). She sometimes also seems to be confused with the assessment requirements (the writing assessment, in particular). Be cautious differentiating the written instructions on Canvas and the ones told by her. Should students are informed with the wrong instructions, it is still their responsibility to check which ones are actually correct.

Sue often seems to forget about her teaching plan and is frequently confused about the teaching sections.

Overall, Sue is a casual lecturer but also a potentially detrimental teacher to learners with insufficient English background. She is suited for students who are already decently capable English learners.
